CARDINAL . Mr. PERSON filed with ORG an appeal on points of law ( Revision ) against ORG judgment . The appeal related to the quantum of his loss of earnings .

In his memorial of CARDINAL DATE , setting out the grounds of appeal ( GPE ) , he complained of ORG failure to grant his request that an expert be heard on the subject of the reports made by other experts concerning his loss of earning capacity ; according to him , ORG should at least have called for a further expert opinion ( LAW ) . He also challenged the method used by ORG for assessing the respective share of responsibility of the persons involved in the accident . A last ground of appeal concerned the question whether ORG was entitled to take into account the social security benefits received by the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG refused to grant Mr. GPE legal aid , on the ground that the appeal offered no prospects of success .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant ’s lawyer asked ORG to hold a hearing in the case . On DATE , its President informed him that the ORG was going to deliberate on the possibility of examining the appeal without oral argument . The President directed that the lawyer should have until DATE to file any observations he might wish to make . The latter acknowledged receipt of this communication on DATE , but submitted no comments . However , on DATE his client sent to him a letter protesting against the proposed procedure . A copy was sent to ORG , but it could not be included with the papers in the case since it was not a document prepared by the applicant ’s lawyer , only the latter having the right of audience before that ORG .

On DATE , the CARDINALth Chamber of ORG , without holding a hearing , unanimously rejected the appeal . Its judgment ( PERSON ) was neither pronounced in open court nor published but was served on the applicant on DATE pursuant to LAW ) , which provides ( translation ) : " decisions adopted by courts after a hearing must be pronounced " and " decisions which are not pronounced shall be communicated to the parties in such manner as may be found appropriate " .
The judgment read as follows ( translation ) :

" Having informed the parties and sought their views ( gehört ) , the CARDINALth ORG , at its session of CARDINAL DATE ... , considered unanimously that it was not necessary to hold a hearing and decided ... :
the appeal ... is dismissed . The appellant is to bear the costs of the proceedings ... "

CARDINAL . The decision not to hold a hearing was based on LAW of CARDINAL DATE ( Gesetz zur Entlastung des Bundesgerichtshofs in GPE ) . Originally this LAW was due to expire on DATE but its validity was extended until DATE by an Act of CARDINAL DATE . The LAW , as so extended , applied to proceedings in appeals on points of law concerning decisions delivered or notified DATE and DATE ; it therefore covered the examination of the applicant ’s appeal , which was directed against a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( sections CARDINAL para . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act ; sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act ; sections CARDINAL para . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of ORG of DATE Gesetz PERSON in GPE ) .
Section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of the Act of CARDINAL DATE provided as follows ( translation ) :

" A court determining an appeal on points of law ( Revisionsgericht ) may take its decision without holding a hearing if it unanimously considers that the appeal is ill - founded and that oral argument is not necessary . The parties shall be informed and asked for their views ( gehört ) beforehand . The judgment ( PERSON ) shall record that the conditions for adopting this procedure are satisfied ; no further reasons need be given . "

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant appealed to ORG against ORG judgment of CARDINAL DATE and ORG judgment of DATE ; in a supplementary memorial of DATE he complained of the above - mentioned legislation itself , relying , inter alia , on LAW .

It considered that , in so far as the appeal concerned the legislation , it was inadmissible as being out of time and that , as regards the judicial decisions complained of , it did not offer sufficient prospects of success since there had been no violation of a right specifically guaranteed by LAW and notably LAW thereof .
